Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They briefly answer a patient’s simple question about over-the-counter pain relief.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was finishing up with a customer at the pharmacy counter. It was Sunday evening—my usual time to call Mom and Dad. I could already imagine Mom’s gentle reminder if I missed it: “We just want to hear your voice, dear.” I glanced at the clock. The store was busier than usual, and a line was forming. A woman stepped up, her face pinched with discomfort, and asked about the best over-the-counter pain relief for her headache. I knew I should take a moment to counsel her properly, explain the options, check for allergies, but my phone kept vibrating. I felt torn—my parents expected our weekly call, a ritual that reassured them I was okay, but my patient needed my full attention. The pressure built in my chest as I weighed the importance of being a good son against my responsibility as a pharmacist. I could feel both roles pulling at me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
